Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I had my first follow-up mammogram Wednesday 30th August and got my all clear result 2 weeks later as promised. I can’t believe people, especially former breast cancer patients, are being expected to wait any longer than I was. All units should offer a similar service.
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: Distraction therapy and physically not being able to see the drugs might help. Ask the nurses to cover the lines with a pillowcase or something. As former paediatric nurse you have to find ways of making things better for the patient. Talk to the nursing staff, as someone else has said they may have encountered a similar problem before. Please don't suffer in silence.
Posts.Title: Psychological revulsion towards intravenous drugs

Posts.Content: That’s fantastic Katie. I think it should be the same for all Breast cancer patients.
Posts.Title: Annual mammogram - how long for result

Posts.Content: I would speak to your GP or a pharmacist. Self medicating is inadvisable in my opinion.
Posts.Title: Can I change back from Anastrazole to Letrozole ?

Posts.Content: Hi Gem I have INC grade1. As all treatment plans are tailored to the individual but you will get lots of support and advice on this forum from people either similar experiences. I have a copy of the IDC booklet on my ipad and found it very helpful xx
Posts.Title: I have just been diagnosed with invasive ductual carcinoma stage 2...

Posts.Content: I have been on Anastrozole for a year or so now. I had the accord brand to start with and a substitute ever since with little or Noe side effects. I am taking a vitamin D supplement which is perhaps why I have no side effects. I have minor aches and pains in my hips and am slow to get going in the morning but apart from that I have little side effects. I have just got a supply of the accord brand from the pharmacy.  I know this is this is of little comfort to you Maggs, so I guess I'm just lucky.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Letrozole & Joint Pain

Posts.Content: I think I'd read about vitamin D on this forum and I asked the pharmacist about it at B***s about it. The brand I'm on now is the one they have . I'm away so don't have the box but it says MA Holder TEVA UK Ltd on the strip. i choose them for my repeat prescriptions hoping to get the Accord brand. However, I have now got it for the first time a year after I started them.  I'm lucky not having many side effects. I've had a knee problem all my life, which was worse to start with, but this has now resolved. Good Luckxx
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Letrozole & Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Thanks for the link to the George website. M&S are missing a trick with their limited range of post surgery bras.
Posts.Title: Bras - rant!!!!

Posts.Content: It is a horrible experience that you are going through. You have the right to be upset and feel like you do. The treatment plan will be YOUR treatment plan. It might be surgery with chemo and or radiotherapy. Please read any information they've given to you at the hodpital. Contact the breast care nurses and look at information on this website. Also find someone who you know and trust to talk to. A neighbour, a colleague or friend. Once you do talk to people you'll discover that there are lots of people who have had breast cancer or know someone that has. Keep visiting this forum you will always have a listening ear. Ask you husband for extra hugs and keep ’talking’  to  him viatext, messenger, face time etc. I am sending hugs too ((((()))))
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Frillyflower. Don't apologise for asking questions. I was where you are two years ago and it is a scary place. You'll find lots of support and advice on this forum. It's what kept me going on the first few months. Don't consult Dr Google come here every time. Everyone's cancer journey is different but we all share a common bond as we travel the same path. xxxx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sally-Lou, it will get better from here on in. When you have your treatment plan you'll have something to focus on, although it can change, mine did, so be prepared for that too. We are lucky having the NHS and wonderful staff. This forum has been keeping me going for the last three months and I'm sure it will do the same for you. Hugs
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Yes they can, sorry forgot to mention that!
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: At one time all underwear had to be removed as it could cause static. As a child I remember wearing paper knickers to the operating theatre. Make-up and nail varnish should be removed so that your skin tone and nail beds are visible. Jewellery has to be removed too, to prevent burns if diathermy is used. These are safety measures and are generic.
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: Yes they can, sorry forgot to mention that!
Posts.Title: Modesty during surgery

Posts.Content: It is very early days and your body needs time to heal. Use the time to read all the books you haven't had time for and watch trashy films, documentaries etc. The weather is so dull and grey this time of year so snuggle up in bed and allow your body to rest and mend itself.  One day at a time xx
Posts.Title: Recovery after mastectomy/diep

Posts.Content: Hi Jemily, It is a scary time but there is a lot of support out there. This forum has kept me going. I am 52 recently diagnosed with Grade 1 Invasive Ductul Carcinoma. I had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy, but now also need a mastectomy. I think its difficult for the onlooker, my sister is really struggling but I'm just taking each day as it comes. I am doing a degree part-time and have found the student support service very helpful. When you return to uni, contact them and let them know the situation. Just be there for your mum, lots of laughter and tears will be par for the course. Lots of girly time and of course lots of hugs. I'm sure there are others who want to 'do their bit so let them. Best wishes for you and your mum xx
Posts.Title: Mum diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I was so relieved when I read this thread as I thought it was just me being a fuddy duddy about the campaign. I think it isn't helpful for someone to shave their head as a form of support. Sorry Macmillan but I think you've got it wrong this time. Continue with your other brilliant fundraising ideas instead.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I just made a comment on a local social media site as the newspaper had done a report about two BRAVE ladies who were shaving their heads. I stated that slit of purple do not like the campaign and although the intention is well meant it is offensive to a lot of cancer survivors. I had one comment that wad very hostile, in a what do yo mean......? tone but then I have had others in support of what I was saying.Macmillan have got this so wrong the Coffee mornings etc. are a much better idea.

Posts.Content: DJ79, I really admire your heartfelt  account about your experience.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I've been on anastrozole for 6 months and continued to have my hair dyed with no ill effects. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole and hair dye.

Posts.Content: Well said jannie13 I have breast cancer and am having surgery so no chemo or radiotherapy but I find the brave the shave campaign highly offensive and I only have short hair. Macmillan have got this completely wrong.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: carolep I would talk yo your friend because your hair will grow back quite quickly, hers won't and will probably never be the same. I know you mean well and you have said the ladies who loose their hair are brave. Do they have a choice? They may not feel brave at all and may be screaming and shouting on the inside but can't show this to the world. X

Posts.Content: I used to watch it and didn't see it today but definitely won't watch again!

Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Totally agree. Count me in.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: So sorry for the late reply. My Macmillan emails keep getting spammed. I hope you do get everything sorted sooner than I have predicted, it use be horrible waiting. No I didn't have diep, I opted for an implant. I have a tissue expander in situ at present and then will have it replaced by a permanent implant. I am also having surgery to my "good" boob, to match it up a little bit. Again this is subject to waiting lists and bed availability. Hope all goes well for you. xxx
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: What a brilliant idea. SHAVE FOR THE BRAVE. I think you may have the solution to the dilemma that this campaign has brought about. The donation of hair to charities such as Little Princess is commendable. Well done sjo 1969.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: If you want to make a complaint then do it. I'm sure the PALS service will help you. I'm not sure what you mean by do complaints work? though. The complaints procedure usually recommends changes are made if the complaint is upheld, and an apology will be issued.
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Pepys, Where I live the pre-op only last six weeks, but everywhere has different policies. However, as an ex nurse I know that operations involving more than one consultant are difficult to set-up. Plus Plastic surgeons are very much in demand and very thinly spread. The type of operation and length of theatre time has to be planned. Sorry,  added to this is the pressure on beds in the winter. Many many operations get cancelled at this time of year, and as yours will be classified as cosmetic, it will not be a priority case. The person who left the message is just being realistic, as they will be adding all these factors in. I know this isn't what you want to hear but this is the NHS in 2016 run by a Tory government. Contact PALS to see if they can help again. The hospital did make a mistake in the first place so you may be classed as a higher priority than most, but I would look to the Spring for your op. I expect to be having the second stage of my reconstruction then too. I have just been put on the list but because of winter pressures I am not expecting a date before March.  Good luck with it all, xxxxx
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: must be horrible .......
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: The hot flushes have stopped too. So onwards and upwards. xxx
Posts.Title: anastrozole- help with lead joints

Posts.Content: Hi millie63, I started taking anastrozole a couple of months ago and felt like you every morning but now I don't so 'hang on in there.' I thought I've got 5 maybe 10 years of this to look forward to, but it stopped after a few weeks. I'm not athletic in any way but found gentle stretching and some walking helped. xxx
Posts.Title: anastrozole- help with lead joints

Posts.Content: Well said frankie45. I too have found the forum invaluable, and got the answers to my questions on the whole. Health and happiness to you this Christmas and always.
Posts.Title: Thank you ALL

Posts.Content: Hi Windmill, I'm so glad you have found this group. Please don't gooogle. I know it's tempting but it could cause you nightmares. Keep using this group and the rest of the Macmillan resources. This is your journey and "we" are all here to support you. xxx
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: Yes definitely get the wine flowing and you can use the bank holiday weekend as an excuse. Sending hugs ((((())))) xx
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: I have had a mastectomy this week and am having an implant. The physiotherapist told me not to attempt to fasten a bra even if you are a twizzler! Someone else needs to do it for you. The ward gave me a softie to wear in my bra for the meantime. I have a couple of post mastectomy bras from M&S but have read that Asda have a good range on line mostly. Thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Bra advice after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I’ve been on an Astro ole for nearly two years. I also take a vitamin D supplement and that seems to have helped with any aches and pains. It works for me it might work for you too.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Turmeric/Curcumin
